Rationale: Revenue decelerates as Americas maturity offsets China growth; EBIT contracts due to estimated $240M tariff impact and inventory clearing.
Americas comps turn deeply negative while inventory overhang forces heavy markdowns; tariffs severely impact gross margins without mitigation.
International growth accelerates to 30%+; effective supply chain pivots mitigate tariff impacts allowing margin preservation.
Product refresh in Spring 2026 stabilizes Americas traffic; margins recover as tariff headwinds normalize and inventory aligns with sales.
New product launches fail to reignite US interest; competition from dupes erodes pricing power permanently compressing margins.
Successful scaling of Men's category and Americas product refresh drives double-digit top-line resurgence; operational leverage returns.
Steady state achieved with China maturing to sustainable growth; buybacks support EPS growth slightly above operating income.
China growth slows rapidly due to geopolitical friction; US market remains stagnant requiring higher marketing spend to hold share.
International expansion beyond China (Europe/APAC) takes hold; gross margins expand to 60% on DTC mix shift.
Growth normalizes to mid-single digits driven by global footprint expansion; SG&A leverage balances slight gross margin pressure.
Market saturation reached globally; cost structure deleverages as fixed costs outpace nominal revenue growth.
Men's category reaches 35% of revenue mix; continued innovation sustains premium pricing despite broader market deflation.
Business reflects mature global retailer profile with cash flow prioritizing shareholder returns over aggressive capex.
Deflationary pressure and lack of innovation turn Lululemon into a legacy brand with shrinking profitability.
Sustained brand heat allows for expansion into adjacent lifestyle categories; operating margins hit long-term peak.
Terminal growth aligns with long-term global GDP and inflation expectations for a premium consumer discretionary staple.
Terminal growth assumes stagnation and loss of market share to emerging competitors in a fragmented sector.
Terminal growth reflects enduring brand equity and successful category expansion allowing above-GDP performance.
